tagline: The hassle-free way to integrate analytics into any web application.
body:
analytics.js
============
**Every project needs analytics.** But having analytics shouldn't mean your tying yourself to a single third-party analytics service and littering your codebase third-party-specific calls. 

Changing or adding new providers should be a snap. That's where **analytics.js** comes in! Instead of adding hooks for every single analytics service you integrate, you add a single set of provider-agnostic hooks that then route to any analytics service you want!

The API is dead simpleâ€”you definitely won't want to go back to using those unfriendly third-party APIs!


## The API
Our goal for the API was to pave over the small differences in all your analytics services to give you a single calls.

### initialize()
To start using **analytics.js**, call `initialize` with the analytics services you want to enable. That looks like this:

```javascript
analytics.initialize({
    'Google Analytics' : 'UA-XXXXXX-XX',
    'Mixpanel'         : 'XXXXXXXXXX',
    'KISSmetrics'      : 'XXXXXXXXXX'
});
```

Did we mention this means you never need to mess with analytics snippets again? Bonus!

You can also choose to pass in extra, service-specific options to enable certain advanced features. Check out the [Service-Specific Reference](#service-specific-settings) for details. That looks like this:

```javascript
analytics.initialize({
    'Google Analytics' : {
        trackingId              : 'UA-XXXXXX-XX',
        enhancedLinkAttribution : false
    },
    'Mixpanel' : {
        token  : 'XXXXXXXXXXX',
        people : true
    },
    'KISSmetrics' : {
        apiKey : 'XXXXXXXXXXX'
    }
});
```


### identify()
Identify is how you tie a user to their actions:

```javascript
analytics.identify('achilles@segment.io', {
    subscriptionPlan : 'Gold',
    friendCount      : 29
});
```

+ `userId` _string_ - is the ID you refer to your user by.
+ `traits` _object, optional_ - is an _optional_ dictionary of things you know about the user. Things like: **Subscription Plan**, **Friend Count**, **Age**, etc.

We usually recommend using a backend template to inject an `identify` with a `userId` straight into the footer of every page of your application. That way no matter what page the user lands on, the call is made.


### track()
Track is how you record the actions your users perform. Whenever a user does something you want to record, `track` that event. The API looks like this:

```javascript
analytics.track('Purchased an Item', {
    price          : 40.20,
    shippingMethod : '2-day'
});
```

+ `event` _string_ - is the name of the event.
+ `properties` _object, optional_ - is an _optional_ dictionary of properties for the event. If the event was **Added to Shopping Cart**, it might have properties like **Price**, **Product Category**, etc.



## How to use analytics.js

1. Grab the latest version of **analytics.js** from this repo and add it to your project.

1. Initialize **analytics.js** with the services you want to use.

1. Add an `analytics.identify()` call to tag your user and some `analytics.track()` calls for the events you want to record.

1. That's it! You're recording data to all your providers!



## Questions

#### Where should I put the identify call?
We usually recommend using a backend template to inject an `identify` call with a `userId` straight into the footer of every page of your application. That way no matter what page the user lands on, the call is made.

#### What traits should I record?
The single most important trait to record is something like `membershipLevel` or `subscriptionType` or however you break your users into different tiers. That way, you can focus on getting people into the higher tiers.

Other things you might want to **identify** are things like **Friend Count**, **Company**, **Business Type**, **Employee Count**, etc.

#### What events should I track?
The best way to figure out what events to track is to ask your to questions: "what do I want my users to do more of?" and "what do i want my users to do less of?". For example:

+ Complete Purchase
+ Upgrade Plan
+ Share on Facebook
+ Watche a Video
+ Invite a Friend

or

+ Cancel their Account
+ Unsuscribe
+ Downgrade Plan
+ Leave Negative Review

#### Google Analytics doesn't have traits! ... Intercom doesn't have events!
That's all right. If a provider doesn't handle a certain method, you can still call it and nothing will break. You don't have to worry about anything.



## Special User Traits

Some special user traits have semantic meaning and are used for specific purposes by different analytics services. (eg. Intercom relies on `email` for messaging). These special traits should only be used for their agreed semantics:

+ `email` - the email address of the user. This gets sent to providers that require an email like Customer.io or Intercom. (We'll automatically pass Mixpanel the `$email` it needs if you use `email`, so don't worry about the dollar signs anymore!)
+ `name` - the name of the user. (Auto-aliases to Mixpanel's `$first_name` and `$last_name`.)
+ `username` - the screen name of the user. (Auto-aliases to Mixpanel's `$username`.)
+ `createdAt` - the date of when the user's account was created. The date format is a [Unix Timestamp](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time) (seconds, not milliseconds!).
+ `lastSeen` - The last time the user visited your site. (Auto-aliases to Mixpanel's `$last_seen`.)



## Provider-specific Settings

### Google Analtyics

+ `trackingId` _string_ - your project's "Tracking ID".
+ `enhancedLinkAttribution` _boolean, optional_ - whether or not to use Google Analytics' [Enhanced Link Attribution](http://support.google.com/analytics/bin/answer.py?hl=en&answer=2558867) feature. Defaults to `false`.
+ `siteSpeedSampleRate` _integer, optional_ - the value to use for Google Analytics' [Site Speed Sample Rate](https://developers.google.com/analytics/devguides/collection/gajs/methods/gaJSApiBasicConfiguration#_gat.GA_Tracker_._setSiteSpeedSampleRate) feature. Google's default is 1%.


### KISSmetrics

+ `apiKey` - your project's "API key".


### Mixpanel

+ `token` _string_ - your project's "token".
+ `people` _boolean, optional_ - whether you want to use Mixpanel's [People](https://mixpanel.com/people/) feature. Defaults to `false`.

_All settings are also passed directly to the second argument of Mixpanel's `init` method._


### Intercom

+ `appId` _string_ - your project's "App ID".

### Olark
No, Olark isn't an analytics provider. But if you have it installed, whenever you call `identify` the Olark chat will update the visitors name, so that you know who you're talking to!

+ `siteId` _string_ - your project's "Site-ID".
+ `track` _boolean, optional_ - whether to log every track call in the operator's Olark chat. This can be useful to know what your users are doing as you're chatting with them, but it can also be overwhelming. Defaults to `false`.


### Chartbeat

+ `uid` _string_ - your project's "User ID".

_All of Chartbeat's [Configuration Variables](http://chartbeat.com/docs/configuration_variables) (`path`, `title`, `domain`, `useCanonical`, `sections`, `authors`, `noCookies`) are also passed directly to Chartbeat's configuration._



## Contributing
We love contributions! If you have a provider you'd like to add, feel free to submit a pull request. Providers are community maintained! You can check out the providers that we've already written for guidance. (Make sure to add tests!)
